stories.title: The Road to Nowhere: A County's Unfinished Dream
stories.excerpt: Three years after groundbreaking, the promised highway connecting rural farmers to markets remains a dusty track. We investigate where the money went.
stories.author: Wanjiku M.
stories.content: In 2021, the county government announced a grand plan: a 40-kilometer highway connecting the agricultural heartland to the main trading center. The budget allocated was 2.5 billion shillings. Today, only 12 kilometers are complete, and the rest remains a memory of broken promises.

stories.title: When the Water Stops Running
stories.excerpt: A town's water crisis reveals a 500 million shilling project that never delivered on its promise to provide clean water to 50,000 residents.
stories.author: Ochieng A.
stories.content: The Shinyanga Water Project was hailed as a solution to decades of water scarcity. Two years and 500 million shillings later, residents still queue at ancient wells.

stories.title: Textbooks in Storage: Why Schools Can't Get What They Need
stories.excerpt: While students share torn books, thousands of textbooks gather dust in a government warehouse. Our investigation reveals a supply chain broken by corruption.
stories.author: Amina K.
stories.content: Government records show 2 million textbooks purchased for primary schools. But a spot check of 50 schools revealed barely 10% received their allocation.

stories.title: The Youth Fund That Youth Can't Access
stories.excerpt: Billions allocated for youth entrepreneurship remain unspent or trapped in bureaucracy. We follow the journey of applicants who gave up.
stories.author: Brian O.
stories.content: The Uwezo Fund was created to provide capital for young entrepreneurs. But application processes, collateral requirements, and corruption have left billions unutilized.

stories.title: Fertilizer on Paper: The Subsidy Scandal
stories.excerpt: Farmers receive vouchers but no fertilizer. Our three-month investigation uncovers a cartel that's starving the agricultural sector.
stories.author: Grace N.
stories.content: Government fertilizer subsidies were meant to boost food production. Instead, we've found a sophisticated network of middlemen diverting supplies to black markets.

stories.title: Hospital Beds, Broken Promises
stories.excerpt: A new county hospital was announced with great fanfare. Two years later, it's a building without equipment, staff, or patients.
stories.author: Dr. Sarah M.
stories.content: The Sunshine County Referral Hospital was budgeted at 800 million shillings. The building stands complete, but without medical equipment worth 300 million shillings.
